elements.content: Solid-state phase transitions in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), composed of metal cations and organic linkers, have been widely reported. They exhibit phase transitions under a variety of stimuli such as pressure, temperature, gas/solvent adsorption, or humidity because of their flexible and responsive structures. Among MOFs, metal phosphonate frameworks are typically more robust than their carboxylate cousins but, accordingly, are more difficult to crystallize. Prototypical are zirconium derivatives which have high thermal and chemical stabilities, making them suitable materials for many applications, e.g., proton conductivity in highly acidic media. However, there are few reports on solid-state phase transitions in zirconium phosphonate MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Solid-state phase transitions in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), composed of metal cations and organic linkers, have been widely reported. They exhibit phase transitions under a variety of stimuli such as pressure, temperature, gas/solvent adsorption, or humidity because of their flexible and responsive structures. Among MOFs, metal phosphonate frameworks are typically more robust than their carboxylate cousins but, accordingly, are more difficult to crystallize. Prototypical are zirconium derivatives which have high thermal and chemical stabilities, making them suitable materials for many applications, e.g., proton conductivity in highly acidic media. However, there are few reports on solid-state phase transitions in zirconium phosphonate MOFs.

elements.content: Better solid proton conductors have precedent as potential fuel cell electrolytes, particularly when they are water stable and highly conducting. Such materials span a number of systems, including (broadly) polymers, solid acids, coordination polymers (CPs), and MOFs, among others. The zirconium phosphonates, in particular, have been a promising platform to design improved proton conductors owing to their robust nature and tunable backbone. Indeed acid-functionalized zirconium phosphonates therein have demonstrated conductivity >10–3 S cm–1 with humidification, although these are largely confined to layered materials. The use of MOFs typically offers a platform to generate useful structure–property relationships, due to the ability to characterize crystalline solids, the combination of which would allow for the design of better materials.
elements.clean_text: Better solid proton conductors have precedent as potential fuel cell electrolytes, particularly when they are water stable and highly conducting. Such materials span a number of systems, including (broadly) polymers, solid acids, coordination polymers (CPs), and MOFs, among others. The zirconium phosphonates, in particular, have been a promising platform to design improved proton conductors owing to their robust nature and tunable backbone. Indeed acid-functionalized zirconium phosphonates therein have demonstrated conductivity >10-3 S cm-1 with humidification, although these are largely confined to layered materials. The use of MOFs typically offers a platform to generate useful structure-property relationships, due to the ability to characterize crystalline solids, the combination of which would allow for the design of better materials.

elements.content: Herein we report a crystalline, dense zirconium phosphonate MOF, (DMA)3[Zr­(HL)­F2] (1, DMA = dimethylammonium, H6L = 2,4,6-tris­(4-phosphonophenyl) pyridine). The sterically rigidified trigonal phosphonic acid ligand (H6L) has been recently synthesized in our group and used to form isostructural barium and strontium MOFs with hydration dependent fluorescence properties. 1 shows an irreversible solid-state phase transition to a semicrystalline–amorphous phase, PCMOF20, at 95% relative humidity (RH) between 70 and 85 °C. Upon reducing humidity or heating under vacuum, it is not possible to regenerate 1. The zirconium phosphonate-based MOFs reported herein contains acidic phosphonate groups and lattice dimethylammonium ions. Compared to 1, PCMOF20 is a porous phase and exhibits enhanced proton conductivity by 3 orders of magnitude after the phase transition.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report a crystalline, dense zirconium phosphonate MOF, (DMA)3[Zr(HL)F2] (1, DMA = dimethylammonium, H6L = 2,4,6-tris(4-phosphonophenyl) pyridine). The sterically rigidified trigonal phosphonic acid ligand (H6L) has been recently synthesized in our group and used to form isostructural barium and strontium MOFs with hydration dependent fluorescence properties. 1 shows an irreversible solid-state phase transition to a semicrystalline-amorphous phase, PCMOF20, at 95% relative humidity (RH) between 70 and 85 °C. Upon reducing humidity or heating under vacuum, it is not possible to regenerate 1. The zirconium phosphonate-based MOFs reported herein contains acidic phosphonate groups and lattice dimethylammonium ions. Compared to 1, PCMOF20 is a porous phase and exhibits enhanced proton conductivity by 3 orders of magnitude after the phase transition.

elements.content: The parent phase 1 was synthesized solvothermally in a Teflon-lined autoclave, by adding H6L (81 mg, 0.15 mmol) to a mixture of 5 mL of DMF, ZrCl4 (34.5 mg, 0.15 mmol), and HF (48%, 0.05 mL) and heating to 150 °C. Colorless block-shaped single crystals were obtained after 96 h. The detailed experimental procedure is provided in the . The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the bulk powdered sample matched that simulated from the single crystal X-ray data ().
elements.clean_text: The parent phase 1 was synthesized solvothermally in a Teflon-lined autoclave, by adding H6L (81 mg, 0.15 mmol) to a mixture of 5 mL of DMF, ZrCl4 (34.5 mg, 0.15 mmol), and HF (48%, 0.05 mL) and heating to 150 °C. Colorless block-shaped single crystals were obtained after 96 h. The detailed experimental procedure is provided in the . The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the bulk powdered sample matched that simulated from the single crystal X-ray data ().

elements.content: 1 is a bilayered structure with apparent voids based on the connectivity between ZrO4F2 octahedra and PO3C tetrahedra, which extends along the a axis via the HL ligands. The Zr atom is coordinated by two fluorine and four oxygen atoms belonging to four different phosphonate tetrahedra (a). All phosphonates are coordinated in a monodentate fashion. Each ligand features three different phosphonate groups: two are connected to the zirconium atoms in a monocoordination mode, of which one is completely deprotonated (P2) and the other one is monoprotonated (P3). The third phosphonate is bicoordinated and completely deprotonated (P1, c). The bilayers stack along the c axis with an AAA sequence, so that every void of one layer is not capped by the SBUs belonging to adjacent layers (b). However, 1 is not porous as all voids are occupied by dimethylammonium ions formed by decomposition of DMF in the presence of water. Stacking occurs via π–π (3.8905(1) Å) interactions between the aromatic rings. Several different hydrogen bonds (D···A distances from 2.592(2) to 2.748(3) Å ()) between the protonated P–O groups from adjacent layers and also between P–O groups and DMA ions augment the stacking. The shortest hydrogen bond distance is between the protonated phosphonate oxygen atom (O7) and another deprotonated phosphonate oxygen atom (O8), while the longest bond is observed between a DMA nitrogen atom (N01) and a phosphonate oxygen atom (O1) (d). The presence of this strong hydrogen-bonded network thwarted attempts to exchange of the DMA cations.
elements.clean_text: 1 is a bilayered structure with apparent voids based on the connectivity between ZrO4F2 octahedra and PO3C tetrahedra, which extends along the a axis via the HL ligands. The Zr atom is coordinated by two fluorine and four oxygen atoms belonging to four different phosphonate tetrahedra (a). All phosphonates are coordinated in a monodentate fashion. Each ligand features three different phosphonate groups: two are connected to the zirconium atoms in a monocoordination mode, of which one is completely deprotonated (P2) and the other one is monoprotonated (P3). The third phosphonate is bicoordinated and completely deprotonated (P1, c). The bilayers stack along the c axis with an AAA sequence, so that every void of one layer is not capped by the SBUs belonging to adjacent layers (b). However, 1 is not porous as all voids are occupied by dimethylammonium ions formed by decomposition of DMF in the presence of water. Stacking occurs via π-π (3.8905(1) Å) interactions between the aromatic rings. Several different hydrogen bonds (D⋅⋅⋅A distances from 2.592(2) to 2.748(3) Å ()) between the protonated P-O groups from adjacent layers and also between P-O groups and DMA ions augment the stacking. The shortest hydrogen bond distance is between the protonated phosphonate oxygen atom (O7) and another deprotonated phosphonate oxygen atom (O8), while the longest bond is observed between a DMA nitrogen atom (N01) and a phosphonate oxygen atom (O1) (d). The presence of this strong hydrogen-bonded network thwarted attempts to exchange of the DMA cations.

elements.content: Single crystal structure of 1 viewed along the (a)abc plane and (b) c axis. Dimethylammonium ions are omitted from the apparent voids for clarity. (c) Different coordination modes of the phosphonates of the ligand, HL. (d) Hydrogen bonding array formed via N–H···O and O–H···O type hydrogen bonds between the DMA ions (blue atoms) and phosphonate groups.
elements.clean_text: 1  Single crystal structure of 1 viewed along the (a)abc plane and (b) c axis. Dimethylammonium ions are omitted from the apparent voids for clarity. (c) Different coordination modes of the phosphonates of the ligand, HL. (d) Hydrogen bonding array formed via N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅O type hydrogen bonds between the DMA ions (blue atoms) and phosphonate groups.

elements.content: Based on the H-bonded array identified in 1, ac impedance spectroscopy was carried out on a powdered sample from 20 to 80 °C at 95% RH to probe potential proton conductivity behavior. b shows Nyquist plots obtained as a function of temperature at 95% RH. Conductivity values at each temperature were measured after an equilibration period of 24 h. Upon heating, 1 demonstrated a significant increase in conductivity: from ∼10–5 S cm–1 at 20 °C to 8 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 70 °C. The maximum conductivity of 1 × 10–2 S cm–1 was obtained at 80 °C (a). This increase was not unlike the phase transitions observed in solid acid superprotonic conductors (i.e., CsHSO4, CsH2PO4). Subsequent heating/cooling cycles revealed stable proton conductivity behavior, with the lowest conductivity now 3 × 10–3 S cm–1 at 20 °C (a, ). The activation energy for proton transfer was 0.2 eV, which is in range for Grotthuss-mediated conduction (). It was evident that 1 underwent a superprotonic phase transition between 20 to 70 °C to form the highly conducting phase, PCMOF20.
elements.clean_text: Based on the H-bonded array identified in 1, ac impedance spectroscopy was carried out on a powdered sample from 20 to 80 °C at 95% RH to probe potential proton conductivity behavior. b shows Nyquist plots obtained as a function of temperature at 95% RH. Conductivity values at each temperature were measured after an equilibration period of 24 h. Upon heating, 1 demonstrated a significant increase in conductivity: from ~10-5 S cm-1 at 20 °C to 8 × 10-3 S cm-1 at 70 °C. The maximum conductivity of 1 × 10-2 S cm-1 was obtained at 80 °C (a). This increase was not unlike the phase transitions observed in solid acid superprotonic conductors (i.e., CsHSO4, CsH2PO4). Subsequent heating/cooling cycles revealed stable proton conductivity behavior, with the lowest conductivity now 3 × 10-3 S cm-1 at 20 °C (a, ). The activation energy for proton transfer was 0.2 eV, which is in range for Grotthuss-mediated conduction (). It was evident that 1 underwent a superprotonic phase transition between 20 to 70 °C to form the highly conducting phase, PCMOF20.

elements.content: (a) Conductivity plot obtained from 1 at 95% RH, from 20 to 80 °C, characteristic of a superprotonic phase transition, where 1 converted to a highly proton conducting phase, PCMOF20, above 70 °C. (b) Nyquist plots for PCMOF20 from AC impedance data at 95% RH on the second cooling cycle.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Conductivity plot obtained from 1 at 95% RH, from 20 to 80 °C, characteristic of a superprotonic phase transition, where 1 converted to a highly proton conducting phase, PCMOF20, above 70 °C. (b) Nyquist plots for PCMOF20 from AC impedance data at 95% RH on the second cooling cycle.

elements.content: To ascertain the role of water vapor on conductivity, variable humidity impedance measurements were conducted at 85 °C. The conductivity value of 1.3 × 10–2 S cm–1 at 95% RH drops to 8.7 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 70% RH and then to 2.5 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 40% RH (). PCMOF20 showed no appreciable conductivity under anhydrous conditions. The high proton conductivity observed under humidified conditions indicates a strong dependence on water in facilitating an efficient proton transfer process. This can be ascribed to the following mechanism. Protons can be obtained from hydrophilic DMA cations which provide dissociable protons in the presence of water. Furthermore, adsorbed lattice water molecules can then facilitate proton transfer to adjacent DMA cations through the hydrogen bonding network (via the Grotthuss mechanism). Similar humidity-dependent proton conductivity has been observed in several MOFs. To date the conductivity value for PCMOF20 is among the highest values for any proton-conducting MOF. Other than PCMOF20 there are only a handful of MOF materials that have obtained the benchmark of 10–2 S cm–1 or higher, which must also be reconciled with water stability.
elements.clean_text: To ascertain the role of water vapor on conductivity, variable humidity impedance measurements were conducted at 85 °C. The conductivity value of 1.3 × 10-2 S cm-1 at 95% RH drops to 8.7 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 70% RH and then to 2.5 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 40% RH (). PCMOF20 showed no appreciable conductivity under anhydrous conditions. The high proton conductivity observed under humidified conditions indicates a strong dependence on water in facilitating an efficient proton transfer process. This can be ascribed to the following mechanism. Protons can be obtained from hydrophilic DMA cations which provide dissociable protons in the presence of water. Furthermore, adsorbed lattice water molecules can then facilitate proton transfer to adjacent DMA cations through the hydrogen bonding network (via the Grotthuss mechanism). Similar humidity-dependent proton conductivity has been observed in several MOFs. To date the conductivity value for PCMOF20 is among the highest values for any proton-conducting MOF. Other than PCMOF20 there are only a handful of MOF materials that have obtained the benchmark of 10-2 S cm-1  or higher, which must also be reconciled with water stability.

elements.content: PCMOF20 was analyzed after impedance analysis and showed dramatic differences. Powder XRD showed much broader peaks and a shift of the lowest angle peak to a much lower 2θ value (a). Before further analysis, PCMOF 20 was prepared outside the proton conduction measurements. At 95% RH and a temperature range of 70–85 °C, 1 transformed to PCMOF20 quantitatively after 10 days. Transformation occurred much faster (within 24 h) if a glass vial of 1 and water was placed into an autoclave and heated to 120 °C. Several other experiments were performed to investigate the phase change under different conditions. For instance, heating 1 up to 150 °C in the DSC instrument (), heating and/or refluxing in water for a month, soaking in water at room temperature for several months, and standing under 95% RH at temperatures lower than 70 °C did form PCMOF20.

Powder XRD showed much broader peaks and a shift of the lowest angle peak to a much lower 2θ value (a). Before further analysis, PCMOF 20 was prepared outside the proton conduction measurements. At 95% RH and a temperature range of 70-85 °C, 1 transformed to PCMOF20 quantitatively after 10 days. Transformation occurred much faster (within 24 h) if a glass vial of 1 and water was placed into an autoclave and heated to 120 °C. Several other experiments were performed to investigate the phase change under different conditions. For instance, heating 1 up to 150 °C in the DSC instrument (), heating and/or refluxing in water for a month, soaking in water at room temperature for several months, and standing under 95% RH at temperatures lower than 70 °C did form PCMOF20.

elements.content: (a) PXRD of 1 and PCMOF20 (obtained after impedance measurements in 95% RH). (b) TGA traces showing differences in hydration between 1 and PCMOF20. (c) N2 sorption isotherm for PCMOF20 at 77 K. (d) Pore size distribution modeled from the N2 sorption isotherm. (e) Water sorption isotherm for 1. (f) Water sorption isotherm for PCMOF20. (g) SEM image of 1 crystals. Scale bar at 200 μm. (h) SEM image of PCMOF20. Scale bar at 20 μm.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) PXRD of 1 and PCMOF20 (obtained after impedance measurements in 95% RH). (b) TGA traces showing differences in hydration between 1 and PCMOF20. (c) N2 sorption isotherm for PCMOF20 at 77 K. (d) Pore size distribution modeled from the N2 sorption isotherm. (e) Water sorption isotherm for 1. (f) Water sorption isotherm for PCMOF20. (g) SEM image of 1 crystals. Scale bar at 200 μm. (h) SEM image of PCMOF20. Scale bar at 20 μm.

elements.content: A variety of spectroscopic and analytical techniques including synchrotron X-ray diffraction, pair distribution function (PDF) analyses, and sorption analyses were used to gain insight into the structure of PCMOF20. PCMOF20 is a semicrystalline material with much higher porosity than 1 but also much higher stability. Its water stability was tested by exposing the sample to 95% RH at 298 K for several months. No changes were observed in the PXRD pattern or proton conductivity. Regarding thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (b) showed a weight loss of 14.5% below 110 °C, attributable to the loss of 8 lattice water molecules (calcd: 15.13%). Above 160 °C, there was a 14.5% weight loss, likely involving loss of the three dimethylammonium ions (calcd: 14.51%). The molecular formula of PCMOF20 was determined as (DMA)3[Zr­(HL)­F2]­(H2O)8 by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, ), elemental analysis (EA, ), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, b).
elements.clean_text: A variety of spectroscopic and analytical techniques including synchrotron X-ray diffraction, pair distribution function (PDF) analyses, and sorption analyses were used to gain insight into the structure of PCMOF20. PCMOF20 is a semicrystalline material with much higher porosity than 1 but also much higher stability. Its water stability was tested by exposing the sample to 95% RH at 298 K for several months. No changes were observed in the PXRD pattern or proton conductivity. Regarding thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (b) showed a weight loss of 14.5% below 110 °C, attributable to the loss of 8 lattice water molecules (calcd: 15.13%). Above 160 °C, there was a 14.5% weight loss, likely involving loss of the three dimethylammonium ions (calcd: 14.51%). The molecular formula of PCMOF20 was determined as (DMA)3[Zr(HL)F2](H2O)8 by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, ), elemental analysis (EA, ), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, b).

elements.content: PCMOF20 was examined for the porosity toward N2 and CO2. It was porous giving a maximum N2 uptake at 77 K of 3.83 mmol g–1. It exhibits a Type I isotherm with a secondary uptake before P/P 0 = 0.1 suggesting a multilayer growth (c and ). The associated BET surface area is 180 m2 g–1. A multimodal pore distribution was modeled using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) giving a wide pore distribution with three maxima at 6, 11, and 19 Å (d). The CO2 uptake of PCMOF20 at 1200 mbar was 2.20 mmol g–1 at 263 K and 1.85 mmol g–1 at 273 K (). The zero-loading heat of adsorption for CO2 was 29 kJ mol–1. More telling of the extent of the structural change between 1 and PCMOF20 is the water sorption data (e,f). While 1 adsorbs a small amount of water (∼0.3 mmolH2O/mmolMOF), PCMOF20 adsorbs ∼75× that amount (23 mmolH2O/mmolMOF). The change in the particle morphology from 1 to PCMOF20 is equally striking as sharp microcrystals convert to a solid with no discernible facets even at 10× higher magnification (g,h).
elements.clean_text: PCMOF20 was examined for the porosity toward N2 and CO2. It was porous giving a maximum N2 uptake at 77 K of 3.83 mmol g-1. It exhibits a Type I isotherm with a secondary uptake before P/P 0 = 0.1 suggesting a multilayer growth (c and ). The associated BET surface area is 180 m2 g-1. A multimodal pore distribution was modeled using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) giving a wide pore distribution with three maxima at 6, 11, and 19 Å (d). The CO2 uptake of PCMOF20 at 1200 mbar was 2.20 mmol g-1 at 263 K and 1.85 mmol g-1 at 273 K (). The zero-loading heat of adsorption for CO2 was 29 kJ mol-1. More telling of the extent of the structural change between 1 and PCMOF20 is the water sorption data (e,f). While 1 adsorbs a small amount of water (~0.3 mmolH2O/mmolMOF), PCMOF20 adsorbs ~75× that amount (23 mmolH2O/mmolMOF). The change in the particle morphology from 1 to PCMOF20 is equally striking as sharp microcrystals convert to a solid with no discernible facets even at 10× higher magnification (g,h).

elements.content: The atomic pair distribution function (PDF) technique, previously used to structurally characterize MOFs, was utilized on the pristine compound 1 and on PCMOF20 to garner more structural insights. Surprisingly, local structure of both compounds (1 and PCMOF20), factoring contacts under 4.5 Å, was nearly identical (). The comparable local structure indicates that the coordination environment around all atoms in PCMOF20 is very similar to those in 1 before exposure to humidity. Ligand distances under 4.5 Å are quite fixed supporting the retention of the dimeric Zr assemblies. Less surprisingly, given the changes in porosity, the long-range atomic correlations above 4.5 Å are quite different between the two phases (, ). Such structural changes indicate that the distances and orientations between aromatic rings are shifted significantly.
elements.clean_text: The atomic pair distribution function (PDF) technique, previously used to structurally characterize MOFs, was utilized on the pristine compound 1 and on PCMOF20 to garner more structural insights. Surprisingly, local structure of both compounds (1 and PCMOF20), factoring contacts under 4.5 Å, was nearly identical (). The comparable local structure indicates that the coordination environment around all atoms in PCMOF20 is very similar to those in 1 before exposure to humidity. Ligand distances under 4.5 Å are quite fixed supporting the retention of the dimeric Zr assemblies. Less surprisingly, given the changes in porosity, the long-range atomic correlations above 4.5 Å are quite different between the two phases (, ). Such structural changes indicate that the distances and orientations between aromatic rings are shifted significantly.

elements.content: Pair distribution function plot of 1 and PCMOF20. Local structures (<4.5 Å) of both compounds are similar, but the medium and long-range structure above 4.5 Å (5 Å shown with a dashed line) is very different.
elements.clean_text: 4  Pair distribution function plot of 1 and PCMOF20. Local structures (<4.5 Å) of both compounds are similar, but the medium and long-range structure above 4.5 Å (5 Å shown with a dashed line) is very different.

elements.content: Here we have presented a robust Zr phosphonate MOF that exceeds the benchmark of 10–2 S cm–1 proton conductivity. PCMOF20 forms by a humidity (95% RH) induced phase change from 70 to 80 °C. The phase change is unusual in that, while pair distribution function analysis shows that the local bonding contacts remain similar, the second, more stable phase is much more porous. PCMOF20 has high thermal and water stabilities, beneficial for candidate electrolyte materials. Further studies of the origin of the exceptional conductivity of PCMOF20 are ongoing as well as studies of a third recently found polymorph.
elements.clean_text: Here we have presented a robust Zr phosphonate MOF that exceeds the benchmark of 10-2 S cm-1 proton conductivity. PCMOF20 forms by a humidity (95% RH) induced phase change from 70 to 80 °C. The phase change is unusual in that, while pair distribution function analysis shows that the local bonding contacts remain similar, the second, more stable phase is much more porous. PCMOF20 has high thermal and water stabilities, beneficial for candidate electrolyte materials. Further studies of the origin of the exceptional conductivity of PCMOF20 are ongoing as well as studies of a third recently found polymorph.

Colorless block-shaped single crystals were obtained after 96 h. The detailed experimental procedure is provided in the . The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of the bulk powdered sample matched that simulated from the single crystal X-ray data ().

cln_elements.content:
A variety of spectroscopic and analytical techniques including synchrotron X-ray diffraction, pair distribution function (PDF) analyses, and sorption analyses were used to gain insight into the structure of PCMOF20. PCMOF20 is a semicrystalline material with much higher porosity than 1 but also much higher stability. Its water stability was tested by exposing the sample to 95% RH at 298 K for several months. No changes were observed in the PXRD pattern or proton conductivity. Regarding thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (b) showed a weight loss of 14.5% below 110 °C, attributable to the loss of 8 lattice water molecules (calcd: 15.13%). Above 160 °C, there was a 14.5% weight loss, likely involving loss of the three dimethylammonium ions (calcd: 14.51%). The molecular formula of PCMOF20 was determined as (DMA)3[Zr­(HL)­F2]­(H2O)8 by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, ), elemental analysis (EA, ), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, b).

PCMOF20 was examined for the porosity toward N2 and CO2. It was porous giving a maximum N2 uptake at 77 K of 3.83 mmol g–1. It exhibits a Type I isotherm with a secondary uptake before P/P 0 = 0.1 suggesting a multilayer growth (c and ). The associated BET surface area is 180 m2 g–1. A multimodal pore distribution was modeled using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) giving a wide pore distribution with three maxima at 6, 11, and 19 Å (d). The CO2 uptake of PCMOF20 at 1200 mbar was 2.20 mmol g–1 at 263 K and 1.85 mmol g–1 at 273 K (). The zero-loading heat of adsorption for CO2 was 29 kJ mol–1. More telling of the extent of the structural change between 1 and PCMOF20 is the water sorption data (e,f). While 1 adsorbs a small amount of water (∼0.3 mmolH2O/mmolMOF), PCMOF20 adsorbs ∼75× that amount (23 mmolH2O/mmolMOF). The change in the particle morphology from 1 to PCMOF20 is equally striking as sharp microcrystals convert to a solid with no discernible facets even at 10× higher magnification (g,h).

Regarding thermal stability, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (b) showed a weight loss of 14.5% below 110 °C, attributable to the loss of 8 lattice water molecules (calcd: 15.13%). The molecular formula of PCMOF20 was determined as (DMA)3[Zr(HL)F2](H2O)8 by energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, ), elemental analysis (EA, ), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, b).

 PCMOF20 was examined for the porosity toward N2 and CO2. It was porous giving a maximum N2 uptake at 77 K of 3.83 mmol g-1. It exhibits a Type I isotherm with a secondary uptake before P/P 0 = 0.1 suggesting a multilayer growth (c and ). The associated BET surface area is 180 m2 g-1. A multimodal pore distribution was modeled using nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) giving a wide pore distribution with three maxima at 6, 11, and 19 Å (d). The CO2 uptake of PCMOF20 at 1200 mbar was 2.20 mmol g-1 at 263 K and 1.85 mmol g-1 at 273 K (). The zero-loading heat of adsorption for CO2 was 29 kJ mol-1. More telling of the extent of the structural change between 1 and PCMOF20 is the water sorption data (e,f). While 1 adsorbs a small amount of water (~0.3 mmolH2O/mmolMOF), PCMOF20 adsorbs ~75× that amount (23 mmolH2O/mmolMOF). The change in the particle morphology from 1 to PCMOF20 is equally striking as sharp microcrystals convert to a solid with no discernible facets even at 10× higher magnification (g,h).

(c) Different coordination modes of the phosphonates of the ligand, HL. (d) Hydrogen bonding array formed via N–H···O and O–H···O type hydrogen bonds between the DMA ions (blue atoms) and phosphonate groups.

Superprotonic Phase Change to a Robust Phosphonate
Metal–Organic Framework
